item.title: Dataset Design: Temporal Concurrency - How
item.description: ## dataset-design-and-temporal-concurrency δI : Information-carrying columns δG : Grouping columns (categorical, descriptive) δY : Measurements (e.g., purchase price, height, product ratings) δT : Temporal columns to include dates and temporal hierarchies δE : Record life-cycle tracking columns (for example, effective dates in slowly changing dimension parlance) Report Window ... members between 30 and 50 years old ... have had at least two inpatient visits within a six-week period Dependence vs.

item.title: Dataset Design: Temporal Concurrency - Who & When
item.description: ## dataset-design-and-temporal-concurrency δI : Information-carrying columns δG : Grouping columns (categorical, descriptive) δY : Measurements (e.g., purchase price, height, product ratings) δT : Temporal columns to include dates and temporal hierarchies δE : Record life-cycle tracking columns (for example, effective dates in slowly changing dimension parlance) Has inpatient visits within 'W' Number of inpatient visits greater than one Time between inpatient admissions less than or equal to six weeks Welcome back!

item.title: Dataset Design: Temporal Concurrency - Prologue
item.description: ## dataset-design-and-temporal-concurrency Introduction Numerous articles have been published centered on data engineering and using data to satisfy a business inquiries. Best practices, techniques, and technology are inescapable concepts one will encounter. What I’d like to present are some design concepts drawn from my own experience specifically dealing with the time-centric aspects of data engineering in the context of deconstructing analytic problem statements. This article serves as the introduction to a short series drawing from my experiences as a data practitioner, specifically focusing on lessons I’ve learned in dealing with temporal co-occurrence.

item.title: Measurements of Scale, Part Two
item.description: ## References (show) Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, and Ratio Scales (Statistics by Jim) Scales of Measurement (Byju's Learning) Level of Measurement (Wikipedia) What is a Distribution in Statistics? (365 Data Science) And we’re back! Be sure to check out Measurements of Scale part one, here. Now, we’ll tackle interval and ratio measurements. Warning: This entry is considerably longer than Part One. If you suffer from TL;DR, please use the “back” button to return to safety.

item.title: Measurements of Scale, Part One
item.description: ## measurements-of-scale References (show) Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, and Ratio Scales (Statistics by Jim) Scales of Measurement (Byju's Learning) Level of Measurement (Wikipedia) What is a Distribution in Statistics? (365 Data Science) A good understanding of measurements of scale (MoS) is essential in both metric design as well as conducting analytics in order to avoid misapplying mathematical operations to the wrong input type leading to misleading or incorrect inferences. References are provided above, so I leave the reader to … well, read.

item.title: Distributions and Some "Mean" Advice
item.description: ## Focal Thoughts: Simply reporting a measure of central tendency presents an incomplete picture of the data under study Choosing the wrong “mean” can mean trouble The values in a dataset should not be interpreted apart from the real-world elements they encode Average Value: Is it Informative? Inevitably, in reading anything involving reported statistics, the average value of some measurement will be reported. What exactly is being reported? Simply put, the “center” of observed values.
